title_sort: john m. rogers to walt whitman, 9 february 1871
title: John M. Rogers to Walt Whitman, 9 February 1871
text: BrooklynFeb 9 1871Dear Father if I may call you soI am well and hearty as ever I received you kind and welcomb[welcome] letter and was to hear that you are enjoying good health I wrote answer to you letter but it got mislaid and I did not mail it I was looking over some letters to day and I came [acrost][[across]] yours so I thought I would [wright][[write]] another We have had very cold weather here this winter and there is a great deal of Ice in the river the Fulton Fery Boats was over and[an] hour going across this morningI am not on the cars any more I had some word with one of the engineers and as I was in the right rather than to have any trouble I told the Presdend[President] I would leave as the weather was so cold and look for something else to do but I have found nothing as yet. I would come to WWashington if I thought I could get any thing to do so good by[bye] for the presant[present]I remain yoursJohnDirect to No. 3 Fulton St.BrooklynN.Y.P.S.Dear Father I should like to see you very much and if you see or hear of any one that wants to get a sober and steady young man, you can wright[write] for me and I will come out there with much loveI remain yourLoving SonJohn M. Rogers John M. Rogers to Walt Whitman, 9 February 1871
